title: Is the expected_shape argument of tf.Variable still useable/useful?
body_html:
• Have I written custom code (as opposed to using a stock example script provided in TensorFlow):
    No
  • OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04):
    Windows 10
  • TensorFlow installed from (source or binary):
    Installed with Anaconda
  • TensorFlow version (use command below):
    b'v1.8.0-0-g93bc2e2072' 1.8.0
  • Python version:
    3.6.5

I know this might be a small docs fix which doesn't fit the issue policy. But I'm not sure and I don't really know how to fix it. I'm sorry. But it seems that the expected_shape argument of tf.Variable has been deprecated for a long time (since v1.0.0). Is it still useable/useful? Is there a reason it is still in the documentation?

tensorflow/tensorflow/python/ops/variables.py

Line 284 in 8753e2e

expected_shape: Deprecated. Ignored.

body:
- **Have I written custom code (as opposed to using a stock example script provided in TensorFlow)**:
No
- **OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04)**:
Windows 10
- **TensorFlow installed from (source or binary)**:
Installed with Anaconda
- **TensorFlow version (use command below)**:
b'v1.8.0-0-g93bc2e2072' 1.8.0
- **Python version**: 
3.6.5

I know this might be a small docs fix which doesn't fit the issue policy. But I'm not sure and I don't really know how to fix it. I'm sorry. But it seems that the `expected_shape` argument of `tf.Variable` has been deprecated for a long time (since v1.0.0). Is it still useable/useful? Is there a reason [it is still in the documentation](https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/Variable#__init__)?

https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/8753e2ebde6c58b56675cc19ab7ff83072824a62/tensorflow/python/ops/variables.py#L284
